instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_REG: What is PP3V3_S5_REG? PP3V3_S5_REG is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU_REG: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU_REG? PPVCORE_S0_CPU_REG is a single phase of CPU VCORE before it is combined into PPVCORE_S0_CPU .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG? PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG Is a single phase of CPU VCORE for the graphics processor integrated into the CPU before it is combined into one PPVCORE_S0_AXG rail.
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.DDRREG_EN: What is DDRREG_EN? DDRREG_EN is an enable signal that turns on power rails for DDR memory.
definitions.P5VS3_EN_L: What is P5VS3_EN_L? P5VS3_EN_L is a signal that enables the PP5V_S3 power rail when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H_REG: What is PP3V42_G3H_REG? PP3V42_G3H_REG is another way to say PP3V42_G3H. PP3V42_G3H_REG and PP3V42_G3H are a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3_OUT: What is PPVRTC_G3_OUT? PPVRTC_G3_OUT is a 3.3v power line that comes out of the clock chip. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video, no mouse
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video, no light at mouse. I have 8.40 at PPBUS and 1.05 at  L7630 PPCPUVCCIO_S0_REG
What is next to check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video, no mouse
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video, no mouse
threads.message:
L7510 - 0V =<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_REG</SIGNAL>
L7550 - 0V =<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG</SIGNAL>
L7330 - 0V =<SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>

No liquid damage

<CHIP>U7300</CHIP>

pin16 - 0.20V
pin17 - 0V

L7220 - 5V =<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
L7260 - 3.3V =<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL>

<RESISTOR>R2530</RESISTOR> - 0V
<RESISTOR>R2570</RESISTOR> - 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video, no mouse
threads.message: Makes no sense, pin 16 on <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> is the same enable as for <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> which is present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video, no mouse
threads.message:
I confirm <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>
pin16 - 0.20V
pin17 - 0V

as I can see <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> has another enable named: =<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL>

and I miss: =<SIGNAL>DDRVTT_EN</SIGNAL> and =<SIGNAL>DDRREG_EN</SIGNAL>

Can you check again. I am wrong?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video, no mouse
threads.message: Look at where <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is generated. <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> is enable for the 3V S5 rail. You say there is 5V on L7220 so <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL> which comes from <TRANSISTOR>Q7911</TRANSISTOR>. <TRANSISTOR>Q7911</TRANSISTOR> is driven by the same bus as <SIGNAL>DDRREG_EN</SIGNAL> through <RESISTOR>R7911</RESISTOR>. So if there is 5V on L7220 the enable for <SIGNAL>DDRREG_EN</SIGNAL> must be high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video, no mouse
threads.message:
Sorry but I cannot find <TRANSISTOR>Q7911</TRANSISTOR> at <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

I started with page 7:

=<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.40V
=<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_REG</SIGNAL> - 3.42V
=<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3_OUT</SIGNAL> 3.3V
=<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> - 5V
=<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL> - 5V
=<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> - 5V
=<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
=<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_FET</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
=<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3_FET</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
=<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_REG</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
=<SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL> - 0V (<CHIP>U7300</CHIP> circuit)

As you can see =<SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL> - 0V is the first rail I miss from page 7.

<CHIP>U7300</CHIP>
Pin2 - 0V
pin12 - 5V
pin6 - 0V
pin16 - 0.2V
pin17 - 0V

<RESISTOR>R2810</RESISTOR> pin1 - 3.3V
<RESISTOR>R2810</RESISTOR> pin2 - 0V
=<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_MEMRESET</SIGNAL> - 5V
<RESISTOR>R2802</RESISTOR> - 5V

[B]Finally I found that I miss <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> at <TRANSISTOR>Q2810</TRANSISTOR> and this is the reason that I miss <SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN</SIGNAL> => =<SIGNAL>DDRVTT_EN</SIGNAL> => which is enable to <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>[/B]

<RESISTOR>R2781</RESISTOR> - 0V
<RESISTOR>R1125</RESISTOR> - 0,13V

<CHIP>U2771</CHIP>
pin1 and pin5 - 3.3V
pin2,3,4 - 0V

Suspect <CHIP>U2771</CHIP>, <CHIP>U2780</CHIP>? Or CPU or PCH?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video, no mouse
threads.message: Could be anything. What happened to this board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video, no mouse
threads.message: Nothing special. No liquid damage. Just one day stoped working.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video, no mouse
threads.message: Maybe BIOS, try another but backup the old.
